body: what did everyone think of detective Pikachu? I loved it! my only complaints were thay Ditto and Gengar were horrifying and that I wish they’d have made Snorlax bigger! but I suppose those are moreso preferences rather than complaints bc I still loved the movie regardless!

blog.name: wits-writing
blog.title: Wit's Writing
blog.description: Reviews of movies, comics, TV shows, and whatever else catches my interest. Feedback is welcomed.

title: Pokémon Detective Pikachu (Quick Movie Review)
body:
Detective Pikachu, directed by Rob Letterman with a screenplay by Dan Hernandez, Benji Samit, Derek Connolly and Letterman himself, presents the first live-action realization of the Pokémon world on the big screen. If realizing that fantastical world from the games/anime/manga in live action were the only metric to judge this movie on, it would be perfect. Seeing these powerful, adorable creatures incorporated into a realistic setting was likely the biggest challenge of getting this movie made at all. Their designs are kept intact from the source material so well and are integrated into the settings as well as any of the best CGI creations from the last few decades of movies I could name have. Anyone who grew up with this franchise is going to find some background element or sequence in the movie worth gushing over. I’m particularly fond of how good it looks when the Pokémon use their elemental powers during the movie’s big action sequences.

The movie’s setting, Ryme City, a place that prides itself on the human inhabitants’ peaceful coexistence with their Pokémon partners, is a wonder of production design going into dedication of making this world believable. From the moment the movie’s protagonist, Tim (Justice Smith), walks into the city we see all the ways the creatures are integrated into the daily functions of the city. The neon lighting and nighttime settings are usually where the movie looks it’s best. Though the CGI-integration occasionally feels less well-done during outdoor, daylight sequences, but even the weak visual moments in that case are only noticeable because of their rarity.

I wanted to frontload my thoughts on Detective Pikachu with how legitimately impressed I was by the design of everything, because I unfortunately found less to dig through in the story. The mystery the movie centers it’s exploration of a Pokémon world around comes down to three elements and how they connect; the disappearance of Tim’s father, why he can understand his dad’s Pikachu (voiced by Ryan Reynolds) and a mysterious chemical with the ability to make Pokémon act wild and start indiscriminately attacking whatever’s around them.

Tim’s disinterest in Pokémon makes a good point for him to start from so he can feel out of place in Ryme City and work as an effective perspective for the audience. He navigates through his own complicated feelings about his dad, while solving the mysteries of the city with Pikachu. The dynamic between Tim and Pikachu is the best thing the movie has going for it outside of the production design, since Justice Smith plays every interaction with the electric mouse convincingly and with a good amount of heart. How the mystery the pair are trying to solve plays out is where some of the movie’s issues lie. In detective stories, a lot of the drama comes from knowing that the characters are figuring things out as they go. However, on multiple occasions in Detective Pikachu, it feels like Tim and Pikachu are being led by the nose to the next plot point rather than putting the pieces together. The ultimate villainous scheme behind the mystery and how it plays out in the third act still end up providing enough spectacle that the plotting getting there doesn’t feel like a waste and still results in some decent moments for the main characters.

Even with the shortcomings I’ve mentioned, Detective Pikachu is worth the time of anyone with even a passing interest in Pokémon in all its forms. The world-building in the background is great, the characters are fun and when the action kicks in it looks as great as you’d want a live-action Pokémon battle to look. If this becomes the basis for more Pokémon movies in the future or even the new metric other video game adaptations try to live up to in terms of faithfulness, it will be fun to see play out.

If you like what you’ve read here, please like/reblog or share elsewhere online, follow me on Twitter (@WC_WIT), and consider throwing some support my way at either Ko-Fi.com or Patreon.com at the extension “/witswriting”

blog.name: speewackfilms
blog.title: The Speewack Watches
blog.description: a kid watching a ton of movies.

summary: Film Review | Pokémon - Detective Pikachu (2019) What a wondrous world that’s been fleshed out in CG for us to see and...
caption:
Film Review | Pokémon - Detective Pikachu (2019)

What a wondrous world that’s been fleshed out in CG for us to see and experience, inhabited by Pokemon and humans. This kind of reality the film portrays is exactly what we, as Pokemon fans, have always wanted. We’re willing to look beyond the hacky script and lackluster human characters with stars in our eyes over living (and working) Pokemon. Maybe because the script and human characters in the game were also not that good??

The film is still an 8 year-old’s fever dream, with all the imagination and spectacle you could ask for. Sure, most of the care in animation went straight into Pikachu and his beautiful big brown eyes - but he had a game all to himself too, what’d you expect!

It’s a fun time at the movies, with some groans too - but that’s OK. I’m sure it’s only the first of many more trips into the cinematic world of Pokemon.

69 of 365.

3.5 out of 5.
